frameDefinitions: In this frame a Speaker ceases speaking, sometimes about a particular Topic.
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer adding some Phenomenon to their model of the world.

A Cognizer possesses knowledge about the workings, significance, or meaning of an idea or object, which we call Phenomenon, and is able to make predictions about the behavior or  occurrence of the Phenomenon.
This frame contains perception words whose Perceivers have perceptual experiences that they do not necessarily intend to.
A Cognizer has a piece of Content in their model of the world.
A person (the Cognizer) comes to believe something (the Content), sometimes after a process of reasoning.
frameExamples: Finally, Jan <t>shut</t> <t>up</t> about his car accident.
Later that night, they <t>found</t> the barely-alive victim inside the Red Hall estate flat.
I figured this out last week and now I really <t>understand</t> it.
Abashed, realising that he had <t>overheard</t> her conversation with Victoria, Sheeley didn't try to make excuses.
Your boss is <t>aware</t> of your commitment.
Based on the most recent census I have <t>concluded</t> that most Americans sleep too much.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Speaker</fen> has previously been speaking but has now stopped.
The <fen>Expressor</fen> is the <fen>Speaker</fen>'s voice or other communicative noise emitted by the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the becoming silent occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location where the becoming silent occurs.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person who becomes aware of a <fen>Phenomenon</fen>. It is normally expressed as an External Argument.
Thm <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is the entity or situation in the world of which a <fen>Cognizer</fen> becomes aware. It is normally expressed as an Object:
This role identifes the <fen>Means</fen> by which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> becomes aware of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
<fen>Topic</fen> indicates the general field within which the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is found.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> uses an <fen>Instrument</fen> to (enable themselves to) become aware of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.  In some cases, the <fen>Instrument</fen> may appear in subject position.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> becomes aware of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The sentient animate being who acquires new knowledge.
A state of affairs or dynamic system whose internal make-up and working the Cognizer comes to assimilate into their knowledge structure.
A part  of a person's cognitive-emotional faculties that is said to acquire knowledge.
This role indicates the when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> asssimilates the new knowledge.
This role is the being who has a perceptual experience, not necessarily on purpose. It is typically expressed as an External Argument.
This role is the entity or phenomenon that the perceiver experiences with his or her senses. It is typically expressed as Object with verbs.
The <fen>Body_part</fen> is the location on the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen>'s body where the perceptual experience  takes place.  It is typically expressed in a PP.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> or the <fen>Body_part</fen> perceives the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The general location within which the act of perception takes place.

The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person whose awareness of phenomena is at question. With a target verb or adjective the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is generally expressed as an External Argument with the <fen>Content</fen> expressed as an Object or Complement.
The <fen>Content</fen> is the object of the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s awareness. <fen>Content</fen> can be expressed as a direct object or in a PP Complement.
Some verbs in this frame allow a <fen>Topic</fen> to be expressed in about-PPs.
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part that reveals the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s state to the observer.
The time interval during which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is aware of the <fen>Content</fen>.
Cognizer is the person who comes to believe something.
Words in this frame may occur with a PP headed by <ment>from</ment> which expresses the Evidence on which knowledge or belief is based:
With a target verb, the Content is usually expressed as a finite clausal Complement or an Object NP, and may sometimes be expressed by a PP:

Some verbs in this frame may occur with postverbal Topic expressions: They <t>found out</t> <fex name='Topic'>about us</fex>! More generally verbs in this frame may occur with quantificational nouns followed by Topic expressions:
An act performed by the <fen>Cognizer</fen> which enables them to figure something out.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the text created by the <fen>Cognizer</fen> to communicate that they came to believe a specified <fen>Content</fen>.
The time at which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> discovers the <fen>Content</fen>.
The location at which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> realizes the <fen>Content</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The children</fex> finally quieted down.
<fex>The excited chatter</fex> hushed.
<fex>Pat</fex> discovered a great little restaurant in Soho.
Pat discovered <fex>a great little restaurant</fex> in Soho.
<fex>By opening the book to page 10</fex>, you will find the Van Eerdens' number.
Scientists attempt to make discoveries <fex>about the laws of nature</fex>.
Olson says the deputy came out to the farm and detected a radioactive substance <fex>with his Geiger counter</fex>.
Robbie had wondered if they would be able to find the path <fex>at night</fex>.
<fex>Sue</fex> grasped the essentials right away
You must grasp <fex>the complex relationship of all these subjects to each other</fex>
<fex>My heart</fex> grasped that reality immediately.
<fex>Yesterday</fex> the students finally grasped the meaning of the equation
<fex>The waiter</fex> smelled something foul in the kitchen.
The waiter smelled <fex>something foul</fex> in the kitchen.
Marlow felt something cold and hard <fex>against the back of his neck</fex>.
<fex>Your boss</fex> is aware of your commitment.
Your boss is aware <fex>of your commitment</fex>.
Kim knows <fex>about first aid</fex>.
Bob's <fex>eyes</fex> were overly aware

Yet there is no evidence that Mr. Parrish was cognizant <fex>at the time of the signing
of the notes</fex> that the clauses in issue were present.
<fex>Sue</fex> realized that Bob was lost.
I have learned <fex>from experience</fex> that poison oak can be painful.
The President learned <fex>that the reporters were hungry</fex>.
The jury learned something terrible <fex>about the suspect</fex>.
<fex>A post-mortem examination</fex> was unable to ascertain the cause of death.
<fex>Back at the tailor's shop</fex>, I deduced that our murderer was not the owner of the kerchief.
